fields.name: Men who have sex with men

fields.text:
HIV stands for human immunodeficiency virus. HIV is transmitted from person to person via the exchange of bodily fluids - semen, blood, and vaginal fluids. HIV destroys a person’s immune system making them more likely to get other diseases that may not harm HIV negative people. AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome) is a later stage of HIV where a person’s immune system is severely depressed.

There is currently no cure for HIV, but there are many medications that can combat the HIV virus that allow people to live long, healthful lives.
fields.title: What

fields.text: We have found that people with hepatitis C, hepatitis B, or tuberculosis are more likely to be infected with HIV.
fields.title: Why

fields.text: Because of the high numbers of men who have sex with men, injection drug users and transfemales who have HIV, we recommend you get tested for HIV every six months.
fields.title: Why

fields.text: In San Francisco, testing for HIV is commonly done by blood draw or finger stick. If your test is a rapid test (meaning same day results are available), a second blood draw may be taken to confirm your initial result. There is a window period of two weeks to six months after an exposure to HIV where someone may be infected, but the test will not be able to pick up the infection. For almost all people the test is able to detect infection by three months after exposure. If you were recently exposed to HIV (e.g., had unprotected sex, shared needles) it is important to re-test in order to close this window period.
fields.title: How

fields.text:
Chlamydia is a bacteria that is spread during vaginal, anal or oral sex , with a partner that has Chlamydia. Many people with Chlamydia don’t experience symptoms, but symptoms may include discharge from the penis, vagina or anus; itching, or pain with urination. In women, untreated Chlamydia can lead to Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) and cause infertility. 

Chlamydia is curable with antibiotics.
fields.title: What

fields.text: We have found a high rate of co-occurrence between Syphilis, Chlamydia, Gonorrhea and Hepatitis B. If you have one of these diseases, we recommend you get tested for Chlamydia when being treated.
fields.title: Why

fields.text: Chlamydia infections are common among adolescents, especially young women. Therefore, we recommend yearly screening for women under the age of 25.
fields.title: Why

fields.text: Rectal and Pharyngeal (throat) Chlamydia is common in men who have sex with men, often without symptoms.  We recommend you get screened for Chlamydia every 3 to 6 months.
fields.title: Why

fields.text: A screening for Chlamydia may include a physical exam and collecting a specimen.
fields.title: How

fields.text:
Gonorrhea is caused by a bacteria that is spread during vaginal, anal and oral sex with a partner that has Gonorrhea. While many experience symptoms with infections in the urethral or penis, infections in the throat, vagina, anus can occur without symptoms.

Gonorrhea infections are completely curable by antibiotics.
fields.title: What

fields.text: We have found a high rate of co-occurrence between Syphilis, Chlamydia, Gonorrhea and Hepatitis B. If you have one of these diseases, we recommend you get tested for Gonorrhea when being treated.
fields.title: Why

fields.text: Gonorrhea infections are common among adolescents, especially young women. Therefore, we recommend yearly screening for women under 25 years of age.
fields.title: Why

fields.text: Gonorrhea infections of the rectum and pharynx (throat) common in men who have sex with men, and can occur without symptoms.  We recommend you get screened for syphilis every 3 to 6 months.
fields.title: Why

fields.text: A Gonorrhea screen may include a physical exam and submitting specimens.
fields.title: How

fields.text:
Syphilis is a sexually transmitted disease caused by a bacteria. It can be spread by physical contact during vaginal, anal, or oral sex. Symptoms can include a painless sore or rash that will go away without treatment.  Although these symptoms will go away, the person is still infected and the bacteria can cause damage to the body.

Syphilis can be cured with antibiotics.
fields.title: What

fields.text: We have found a high rate of co-occurrence between Syphilis, Chlamydia, Gonorrhea and Hepatitis B. If you have one of these diseases, we recommend you get tested for Syphilis when being treated.
fields.title: Why

fields.text: Syphilis is common among men who have sex with men and transgender people.  Therefore, we recommend you get screened for syphilis every 3 to 6 months.
fields.title: Why

fields.text: Syphilis is typically diagnosed by physical exam and a blood test.
fields.title: How

fields.text:
Hepatitis C is a contagious liver infection caused by a virus spread by blood to blood contact. Approximately 15% of people infected with hepatitis C naturally fight off the virus. However, most people infected with hepatitis C will become chronically infected, meaning the virus does not go away on its own in six months. If left untreated, these people will live with the infection for the rest of their lives. Most people infected with the hepatitis C virus have no symptoms and may live decades before they experience any. Untreated, hepatitis C may lead to numerous complications, including cirrhosis (scarring of the liver), liver cancer, and death. Hepatitis C is the leading reason for liver transplants in the United States.

For some people living with hepatitis C, treatment  with anti-viral medications may provide a cure. However, treatment is not appropriate for everyone. The decision to treat must be made by an individual in consultation with his/her doctor.
fields.title: What

fields.text: If you inject drugs, you may be at risk for the hepatitis C virus. We recommend you get a test every year.
fields.title: Why

fields.text: If you have ever  injected drugs, even once many years ago, and have not been tested for hepatitis C, we recommend you get a test.
fields.title: Why

fields.text: Hepatitis C virus infection is most common among adults born from 1945 through 1965. Approximately 75% of infected adults are unaware they are living with hepatitis C. Because people living with hepatitis C may not experience symptoms for many years after becoming infected, the risk for serious complications increases among this group over time. Thus, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that all individuals born during this time period, those of the “Baby Boomer” generation, test for hepatitis C once in their lifetime.
fields.title: Why

fields.text: If you are from a country with a high rate of hepatitis C infection, we recommend you get a test.
fields.title: Why

fields.text: A blood draw is required to test for hepatitis C. The initial test looks for the body’s reaction to the virus (antibodies). There is a window period of two weeks to six months after an exposure to hepatitis C where someone may be infected, but the test will not be able to pick up the infection. For almost all people the test is able to detect infection by three months after exposure. If you were recently exposed to hepatitis C (e.g., shared needles) it is important to re-test in order to close this window period. If the first test is reactive (positive), additional testing will be required to confirm chronic infection.
fields.title: How

fields.text:
Hepatitis B is a contagious disease caused by infection of the liver with the hepatitis B virus. This infection can lead to cirrhosis of the liver, liver failure, and liver cancer. 80% of liver cancer worldwide is caused by hepatitis B virus infection.

The hepatitis B virus can be spread by having contact with the blood, semen, vaginal fluids, or other body fluids of someone who has a hepatitis B infection.
fields.title: What

fields.text: We recommend you get screened for hepatitis B to diagnose a past or present infection.
fields.title: Why

fields.text: Since you are HIV Positive and have a lowered immune system, we recommend you get tested for hepatitis B.
fields.title: Why

fields.text: If you are from a country with a high rate of hepatitis B we recommend you get screened for hepatitis B.
fields.title: Why

fields.text:
Hepatitis B is diagnosed from a blood test. This single blood test can determine if you are infected by hepatitis B and are contagious, or have had hepatitis B in the past.

If you do not have hepatitis B and have not been vaccinated against hepatitis B, we strongly recommend you get a hepatitis B vaccination.
fields.title: How

fields.text:
Hepatitis B is a contagious disease caused by infection of the liver with the hepatitis B virus. This infection can lead to cirrhosis of the liver, liver failure, and liver cancer. 80% of liver cancer worldwide is caused by hepatitis B virus infection.

The hepatitis B virus can be spread by having contact with the blood, semen, vaginal fluids, or other body fluids of someone who has a hepatitis B infection.
fields.title: What

fields.text: We have found that people in San Francisco who have tuberculosis are more likely to have hepatitis B.
fields.title: Active TB

fields.text: We recommend that you get vaccinated against hepatitis B because HIV makes you more susceptible to infections.
fields.title: Why

fields.text: National policy states that  all children must be vaccinated for hepatitis B. We additionally recommend that all adults should be vaccinated against hepatitis B.
fields.title: Why

fields.text:
The hepatitis B Vaccine is a series of three injections that need to be administered over six months. After receiving all three injections, a person in believed to be vaccinated for life.

You will be tested for hepatitis B before being vaccinated, to make sure you do not already have hepatitis B.
fields.title: How

fields.text:
Tuberculosis is a  disease that usually affects person’s lungs, but can occur in any part of the body. This infection is typically spread from person to person through the air when one person coughs or sneezes. Tuberculosis infection can be fatal if left untreated. 
 
People who have tuberculosis may not feel sick but have a small amount of tuberculosis bacteria that are kept under control by their immune system.  If the immune system is not able to contain the infection, then the person will progress to active tuberculosis disease.  When people have active tuberculosis disease, they usually have symptoms like fever, weight loss, fatigue, and cough and can spread tuberculosis to other people.
fields.title: What

fields.text: People with viral hepatitis often fall into the same groups of people who have been exposed to TB, so may benefit from a screen for tuberculosis.
fields.title: Why

fields.text: Since you are HIV positive, we recommend you get tested annually for tuberculosis.  HIV positive people who are infected with TB are at a very high risk for progressing to active TB disease.  If you are HIV positive and have TB infection, you can get preventive treatment.
fields.title: Why

fields.text: Unless you are  at risk for exposure to tuberculosis or are experiencing symptoms of tuberculosis, we don’t recommend you get tested.
fields.title: Why

fields.text: Visit San Francisco Tuberculosis Control for a complete list of testing sites.
fields.title: Where
